description.narrative: SUMMARY The Girls Advocacy Alliance Sierra Leone is a five year programme (2016-2020) that consists of Plan International Sierra Leone and DCI-Sierra Leone, together with local CSO partners. Through lobby advocacy, the programme urges government representatives, traditional and religious leaders, private sector agents and communities at large, to improve the implementation of existing policies, in particular in relation to child marriage, FGM, sexual violence and abuse, equal access to post-primary education and entrepreneurship for young women. Building upon the results of the Girl Power programme (2011-2015), the target areas of the Sierra Leone country programme are Western Area (i.e., Western Area Rural District and Western Area Urban District) and Moyamba District. Nonetheless, some of the programme’s advocacy efforts, particularly at government level, will have a national reach.

The Girls Advocacy Programme builds on the outcomes realised, lessons learned and relationships built up by the three alliance organisations during various programmes. An example in Sierra Leone is the Girl Power Programme that was implemented from 2011 till 2015 by an alliance of six Dutch NGOs, including lead organisations Plan Nederland and Defence for Children – ECPAT Nederland.
The Girl Power Programme focused on the political and socio-economic empowerment of girls and young women, making them better protected against sexual and other forms of gender based violence and improving their access to secondary education. The Girls Advocacy programme in Sierra Leone will build on the thematic expertise and partnerships that were gained during the Girl Power Programme. For example, during the Girl Power programme Plan Sierra Leone and implementing partners managed to build productive and collaborative relationships with government institutions responsible for addressing gender based violence.

The Sierra Leone country programme aims to contribute to four long term strategic goals: 1) Increased public support, at community/local level, for girls’ and young women’s (equal) access to post-primary education and entrepreneurship opportunities, and the elimination of child marriage, FGM and sexual violence & abuse. 2) Improved implementation by government of the Child Rights Act, the Memorandum of Understanding between Paramount Chiefs and the Family Support Unit of the Police; the Sexual Offences Act; the (harmonised) Registration Customary Marriages and Divorce Act; and the Teacher’s Code of Conduct. 3) Increased influence by child rights CSOs and Child Rights Coalition Sierra Leone on government and local businesses in ensuring the rights of girls and young women to economic empowerment and protection against gender based violence. 4) Local businesses increasingly demonstrate a strong commitment for ensuring equal economic opportunities for young women.
Plan Sierra Leone and DCI-Sierra Leone will work with a wide range of partners and duty bearers to constructively bring about change. The Advocacy strategy and process will be based on demonstrated evidence, to directly and indirectly influence decision makers, stakeholders and relevant audiences.

The advocacy interventions include: - mobilization of champions of change to mobilize, lead and influence others - engagement of traditional leaders (soweis), paramount chiefs, tribal headmen through trainings to effect change and address the issues of GBV and sexual abuse cases - peer to peer education in schools, schools assembly talk and involvement of school authorities in lobby and advocacy meeting in schools - engagement of District Council to develop a District child protection plan and form a District Gender Task Force Committee - advise and lobby towards government officials in line ministries and parliamentary representatives - capacity development support to CSO partners to strengthen their lobby and Advocacy capacity

The entrenched socio-cultural and religious norms and beliefs continue to affect the lives of girls and young women. They slow down transformations in social relations and restrain the implementation and enforcement of adopted laws and policies around gender equality. Despite legislative reforms, girls and women continue to experience discriminatory practices. Their rights and position are largely contingent on (local) customary laws and the ethnic group to which they belong.
In addition to the socio-cultural factors, the implementation of relevant gender equality and child protection laws is further weakened by a lack of human, technical and financial resources. Another complicating factor is Sierra Leone’s dualistic legal system. Approximately 85% of Sierra Leoneans are under the jurisdiction of customary law, and the informal justice system is more relevant to their lives than the formal justice system. The customary laws can be highly discriminatory towards women and girls, and children, and harmonisation with formal/national legislation is lacking including on child marriage.

title.narrative: Number of gender-responsive national and subnational COVID-19 Response Plans and management processes

comment.narrative: Number of gender-responsive national and subnational COVID-19 Response Plans and management processes

title.narrative: Number of COVID-19 management processes in which government policy makers, UN agencies and NGOs have included young people's participation and/or respond to the young people's advocacy ask around the response to COVID-19

comment.narrative:
The priject, a.o, provide technical and logistics support to Ministry of Social Welfare Gender and Children’s Affairs to coordinate the psychosocial pillar on COVID-19 ensuring that girl’s rights issues are addressed within the district COVID-19 response plan.
The project also supported contributed to the popularization of a One Stop-Centre established by the Government of Sierra Leone with support from UN Women.
The project, supported the gender rapid assessment by Institute of Gender Research and Documentation (INGRADOC) Fourah Bay College, University of Sierra Leone (FBC/USL). The assessment aimed to provide a perspective into the situation of women and girls in six districts during the COVID-19 pandemic in six (6) districts. This assessment looked at the gender dynamics and provided an analysis of the same by sectors and proffer recommendations for improving gender mainstreaming during and possibly after the COVID-19 pandemic.
This has enhanced and further strengthened gender mainstreaming in project operation areas within the districts.
